moves.1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. Nc3 Qc5 4. d4: Chasing your queen around the board to develop my pieces.
moves.7. O-O Nc6: Black is trying hard to catch up with development now.
moves.8. Bf4 Nf6 9. Nb5: Setting up for a possible Queen trap that I learned from Kasparov vs Letterman.
moves.10. Ne5 Nxe5 11. Bxe5 Rg8: I hope you plan to castle Queenside, because moving your rook means you can't castle Kingside now. I know that too now, which makes it easier to plan attacks on the Queenside.
moves.12... b6: You missed the incoming combo. In fact this move makes it worse.
moves.13. Bxd5: Any way you chalk it up, you're about to lose a lot of material.
Why didn't I defend my Bishop? I don't remember. Was I sacrificing it for a mate solution in my head? I can't find that now, for all I know I've left him to die.
moves.16... Bh6: No matter, he doesn't even notice the hanging Bishop.
moves.17. Rfe1: His pieces are still very far away. Time to set up my attack. Here not only do I defend the Bishop but I move my Rook in line with the King.
moves.17... Ba6: I'm sure he's trying to set up some kind of attack.
moves.19. Bc6+: This combo will end with a captured Queen.
Sexcellent. I hope it captures the rook, it leads to a forced mate.
The choice between the queen and the bishop was a tough one. Bishops don't get enough action.
